items.title: Primary diagnosis and staging
items.summary: Initial workup confirmed lymphoma; baseline tests and staging completed.
items.details: Symptoms led to hematology consult. Imaging and biopsies established the diagnosis and stage. Baseline echocardiogram and labs recorded prior to therapy.

items.title: R‑CHOP chemotherapy (6 cycles)
items.summary: First‑line regimen completed with supportive care.
items.details: Six cycles approximately every 21 days. Interim imaging showed response; end‑of‑treatment assessment documented best response achieved.

items.title: Cell therapy with inpatient recovery
items.summary: Cell infusion under protocol; complications managed during hospital stay.
items.details: Cell therapy administered with neuro/cardiac monitoring. Complications included high fever and weakness; stabilized and discharged to step‑down care/rehab.

items.title: Critical systemic shock and paralysis episode
items.summary: Acute collapse during a video call; emergency hospitalization and paralysis.
items.details: On March 26, 2022, Adam experienced a systemic shock with loss of function. Hospital course included loss of memory, slowed cognition, and paralysis. Gradual return of consciousness; began to eat and sleep; remained optimistic despite severe condition.

items.title: Unsafe discharge; protective suit; temporary housing
items.summary: Discharged in profound immunosuppression; urgent need for protective gear and shelter.
items.details: Oncologist urged urgent purchase of a protective suit; Adam was temporarily placed in a motel. Later he moved to his apartment where additional caregiving issues arose; an unprofessional nurse was replaced by Melissa.

items.title: Sedation/poisoning incident and police involvement
items.summary: Unknown woman entered, Adam was sedated and found without memory; legal turbulence escalated.
items.details: Water intended for Adam’s brother was used to sedate Adam; he was taken by police with amnesia. Guardian conflicts and attempts to access the apartment followed. Planned free rehab collapsed after a crisis with the oncologist, leading to cardiac distress.

items.title: Large abdominal tumor found; new Hodgkin lymphoma
items.summary: Imaging discovered a large mass; aggressive Hodgkin lymphoma diagnosed.
items.details: During hospitalization for an injury, imaging incidentally revealed a large abdominal tumor. Further workup suggested aggressive Hodgkin lymphoma, considered distinct from earlier disease and possibly a CAR‑T side effect. New chemotherapy was proposed.

items.title: Oral multi‑agent chemotherapy (14 doses)
items.summary: Current course: complex per‑oral regimen at home, total of 14 doses.
items.details: Adam is on a structured oral chemotherapy made of multiple components (per os). The plan includes 14 doses with careful monitoring of tolerance, labs, and functional status.

items.title: Second‑opinion board & treatment decision
items.summary: Multidisciplinary review to confirm options and timing.
items.details: Case to be presented to a board (hematology/oncology/rehab). Decision may include watchful waiting, targeted therapy, or enrollment in a program. Timing depends on diagnostics and logistics.

items.title: Support and recovery program
items.summary: Structured support and functional recovery after the current oral course.
items.details: If indicated after evaluation, a block of supportive care and rehabilitation will follow. Scope, schedule, and venue to be refined.

items.title: Extended rehabilitation program
items.summary: Longer rehabilitation block may be required depending on status and resources.
items.details: May proceed only if clinical course and resources permit. Details remain uncertain.

changelog.note: Initial filled roadmap (EN). Removed locations. Current step updated to oral multi‑agent chemotherapy (14 doses). Added 2022 shock, 2023 sedation incident, 2024 new tumor and Hodgkin lymphoma.
